content:
Hi Punit,
The response looks pretty straightforward, but I'm not much of a C# expert these days to be able to give a very good answer for what you're trying to do. I'd suggest either looking at the O'Reilly "Programming C#" books, or maybe post in one of the C# forums. Good luck!

content:
I was having a lot of trouble getting JSON examples from this and other places I Googled to run. VS2010 wouldn't compile the samples, usually something like:

using System.Web.Script.Serialization;   // VS 2010 compile err!!! module not found!

Found the clue I was looking for in here, which was:

>>>>>>> Add a reference to your project to 'System.Web.Extensions.dll'

In the project explorer pane, open "References", click on "Add" and you can select from a whole bunch of references that are NOT included in a project by default, including the Web.Extensions.dll. Once I did that, things seemed to work pretty well, but finding this site with the clue took quite a few frustrating hours.

Thanks!!!
author: Ken

content: Excellent article. Helped me with my exact needs for Json (this after I searched google for 2 hours).
author: San

content:
This article helped me immensely. I was trying to deserialize some JSON put out by Twitter's API that has nested lists, and for the life of me I just could not figure out how to access the child elements of those nested lists. The key for me here was using "dynamic" in the Dictionary overload, and putting the Dictionary into List form. Then I was able to get at those elements.
MANY thanks!
author: Will

content:
Hi, many thanks for your great example. 
Your first statements could raise expectations that all examples work with .NET 3.5 framework (and so: VS 2008). But the "dynamic" keyword is introduced in C# 4.0 which means you need at least VS 2010.

content:
Thanks for the compliment. 

I'm not sure why you would want to deserialize to an array of dictionaries though? I think it makes the most sense to deserialize to the dynamic data type.
